snippet: The findings undercut the idea that NATO could effectively carry out a more complicated campaign in Syria without relying disproportionately on the United States military.
abstract: Confidential NATO assessment on its campaign in Libya concludes that the alliance struggled to share crucial target information, lacked specialized planners and analysts, and overly relied on the United States for reconnaissance and refueling aircraft; findings undercut the idea that the intervention was a model operation and that NATO could effectively carry out a more complicated campaign in Syria without significant US assistance.
lead_paragraph: The findings undercut the idea that NATO could effectively carry out a more complicated campaign in Syria without relying disproportionately on the United States military.

headline.seo: NATO Sees Flaws in Air Campaign Against Qaddafi
